newsitem.title: ZIMBABWE: Issues at Zimbabwe CITES conference.
newsitem.headline: Issues at Zimbabwe CITES conference.

text.p: A 10-day conference of the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species (CITES) beginning in Zimbabwe on Monday is expected to be dominated by the following issues:

- proposal by Botswana, Namibia and Zimbabwe for CITES to partially lift a 1989 world ban on ivory trade to allow the three elephant-rich southern African states to trade ivory regularly culled from their 150,000 herd.
- proposal by Norway and Japan to open up whale-hunting, especially for scientific studies.
- petition by South Africa that it be allowed to trade white rhinoceros products, expanding on current limits to export just its live animals.

- debate on ways to cut down illegal trade in endangered species, currently estimated by CITES at up to $10 billion a year. Monkeys, live birds, reptile skins, tropical fish, orchids, snowdrop bulbs, cacti and snakes are among those heavily traded.

- measures to further protect the Indian tiger, the black rhino, the rare sturgeon fish, the Cuban sea turtle and the Peruvian butterfly, which are among species which many "green" environmental and animal watchdogs say are severely threatened.
